post.title: /u/ZorbaTHut uses CCG meta to teach us about the inanity of recommending reforms without identifying tradeoffs

div.p: So there's this guy called Day9.
(Bear with me, I'm going somewhere with this.)

Day9 is a game streamer online. I frankly don't know what he's best known for at this point, he's been doing game streaming online since before game streaming online was a thing. One game he plays a bunch of is Hearthstone.

Hearthstone is a collectible card game similar to Magic. You have a deck of 30 cards and you try to use those cards to kill your opponent. If they pull out something clever and you don't have a card with a response to it, then you probably lose.

For a long time, whenever he would play Hearthstone, he would be barraged by suggestions. "Add a Dark Iron Dwarf!" "If you'd have Electra Stormsurge, he'd be dead by now!" "You could have survived that with Kronx Dragonhoof!" These suggestions were generally accurate, but also useless.

Because, remember, you have a deck of 30 cards. You do not have a deck of "30 cards, plus Electra Stormsurge I guess." You can't just add things; every card you put in your deck is also a card you have to take out of your deck.

So eventually he had a new policy. If you wanted him to add a card, you also had to tell him what card to take out. The barrage immediately stopped; it's much much easier to recognize that magically adding a card is a good idea than it is to recognize which card should be removed in its favor.
I think you're right. Teaching people Latin and Greek would be nice. If we could do that for free, we should do it.
But we can't. School days are already far too long, and we already don't have enough money to provide the good schooling you want to introduce.
So: Okay, that's a proposal. What do we remove in its favor? You want two years of classical civilization education; tell me what two years of existing education you're willing to throw away.
Then we've got something to talk about.
